So we're really excited moving forward um looking at taking some of our fret based fluorescent biosensors and uh developing them for swear imaging for in vivo use um and uh uh one of our we're trying to make some translational materials also. So starting with biocompatible and biodegradable semiconductor nanocrystals and then developing their optical properties rather than starting with things first made for solar cells and uh LED lights, maybe make them for a biological approach and then develop the optical things. speaker: Arnold Hayer
transcript: Hi, my name is Arnold Hayer. I'm a an assistant professor at McGill University in the Department of Biology. I've run my lab now for about three years. And uh the research program that we are pursuing is uh interested in understanding the signaling networks that govern cell migration and we are using cultured endothelial cells as a model system and we're interested in both the signaling dynamics in individual cells um but also how these signaling dynamics in individual cells are coordinated between neighboring cells during collective cell migration. And uh we have a a two-dimensional model for collective cell migration which is basically just monolayers and cells are moving within the monolayers but also three-dimensional migration and and morphogenesis, which is something endothelial cells do. So a lot of our work relies on fluorescence imaging using um probes, reporters for cytoskeletal structures or for um for fret based fret based probes for activities such as ro GTPases. So we're tracking cells but in in in single cells we're also tracking um regions of cells like protrusions, retractions and trying to relate those morphogenetic processes to signaling activities.

annotations.develop idea: Arnold expands on his research program, providing details about their model systems and methods.

speaker: Arnold Hayer, McGill
transcript: and analysis to achieve that because in 3D you need advanced techniques that are not yet accessible to everyone like lattice light sheet light sheet microscopy and and very reliable computational tools for for tracking individual cells in in those in those systems which I think should in principle be technically possible like tracking in 2D is is pretty trivial in 3D it's much much harder but I think it's it could be done given the imaging techniques that we have then in addition to just tracking it would be nice to have additional properties for each one of the cells like signaling activities some reporters about what's what's going on what state they are what differentiation mode they might have and I I think this is this would potentially allow us to learn more about the fundamental properties of of cellular interactions of organ development which and again if they are not going right then you you would enter a disease state.

speaker: Shwetadwip Chowdhury, UT Austin
transcript: So in um so in optical imaging so my field is optical imaging we uh so we our field specializes in uh imaging resolution um and so we are actually very uh like imaging like cells and even subcellular features are very well within our capabilities. Um but in terms of um but in terms of answering the question about how can we see cells as they migrate through actual organisms the reason that gets difficult is our pain point is imaging through scattering tissue which is whenever you get into bigger biology that's what we struggle with. Like MRI CT pet they we're a lot more um limited by that than the other modalities are. That said uh there is there are a few hybrid approaches are coming in. And so at least for small organisms like um you know like zebrafish or maybe uh even a mouse brain where you like take off the skull and you put like a transmission window through it. In these types of uh specific scenarios there are systems where uh you kind of get pseudo optical resolution but with a lot greater uh penetration depth into the scattering tissue. Um and so I wonder if there's a way to track cells at least in that first millimeter or so depth into the scattering tissue and that might be really important for specific applications where maybe the cell you care about isn't going to go through the whole organism it's only is going to be localized to like the surface areas of the brain or of the spinal cord or whatever. Um and so some technology that I'm really excited about in this space uh like are like of course you have the normal very uh popular optical technologies like confocal and light sheet and stuff like that.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker expands on existing ideas about optical imaging challenges and potential solutions.
annotations.offer feedback: The speaker suggests potential solutions and technologies for improving cell tracking in biological organisms.
annotations.identify gap: The speaker highlights the limitation in current imaging capabilities, specifically in imaging through scattering tissue.

speaker: Shwetadwip Chowdhury, UT Austin
transcript: But there are also another another uh set of hybrid imaging techniques that are coming out that are not based on just optics that are that use sound for example like photoacoustics.

annotations.propose new idea: The speaker introduces a new concept of hybrid imaging techniques that use sound, such as photoacoustics, which has not been mentioned before in the discussion.
annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on previous ideas about imaging techniques by suggesting an alternative approach that uses sound.

speaker: Shwetadwip Chowdhury, UT Austin
transcript: Um where they're trying to excite light and based on the heating of the of the sample like acoustic waves come out and you measure that. And one of the benefits of this is that it's a label free. Um so it's basically the contrast it's well it doesn't have to be label free but it was initially presented as label free where the contrast is coming from um absorption. So of course you can introduce exogenous particles that are absorptive to give higher contrast to specific specific components.

annotations.propose new idea: The speaker introduces photoacoustics as a label-free imaging technique.
annotations.develop idea: The speaker elaborates on the benefits and methodology of photoacoustics.
annotations.identify gap: The speaker discusses challenges in imaging through scattering tissue.

speaker: Shwetadwip Chowdhury, UT Austin

And so I've always wondered sort of why um you know people haven't sort of focused on um you know contrast like instead of contrast injectable contrast dies but contrast lipids or whatever that would be labeling single cells or that would be I don't know we we talked about actually like injecting iron or like soaking the cells in iron and then trying to chase them around in in our CT one time but of course I didn't have the bandwidth to do that.

transcript: Brian just to uh talk of tools. I Allison you were um mentioned swear quantum dots. I mean I don't how far have you got are you actually doing swear imaging or is this just something you're working towards or uh.

speaker: Allison Dennis, Boston U (she/her)
transcript: Yeah, so we're able to send our our contrast agents to a collaborator who has both um a whole animal pre-clinical imager and the microscope our pre-clinical imager has been on order for many months and COVID delayed.

annotations.None: No specific code directly applies as the utterance primarily provides an update on equipment status and collaboration rather than engaging in the specified types of interactions.

speaker: Allison Dennis, Boston U (she/her)
transcript: Um but we're getting a hyperspectral imager this year. Um so for us for with the QDs that's really nice because we'll be able to look we get a ton of signal out. Um the resolution for optical pre-clinical fluorescence imaging is gorgeous but background is super low. Um and with a hyperspectral we'll be able to do multi multiplex um imaging. So we'll we'll have to get the imager and push the limits on what the sensitivity is and uh how much light throughput we get of course. Um the problem with the hyperspectral is you're you're chopping up your signal so um integration times get longer.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is elaborating on the benefits and limitations of the hyperspectral imager.
annotations.signal expertise: The speaker mentions specifics about the equipment and its applications, indicating some level of expertise.
annotations.identify gap: The speaker mentions a limitation of the hyperspectral imager (integration times get longer).

speaker: Allison Dennis, Boston U (she/her)
transcript: But with the if you're doing just filter imaging the I'll show videos later there you get you can get uh you can watch the mouse breathe and then track heart rate and things because the the speed of the video frame rate is um really nice.

annotations.supportive response: The speaker is expressing a positive evaluation of the imaging technique's capability.

speaker: Allison Dennis, Boston U (she/her)
transcript: So the swear imaging I'm actually a pretty big fan of and one of the things that we're looking at when you guys talk about and so I'm curious what others experiences um we don't do uh bioluminescence imaging or haven't historically.

speaker: Allison Dennis, Boston U (she/her)
transcript: But uh in order to be more specific about uh to focus on both the excitation and emission side we're looking at Brett probes where you would use luciferase to excite the swear emitting QDs so you don't have to worry about the excitation side of things. Um and that also gives us a handle for sensing rather than just tracking.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker elaborates on the benefits of the approach, including focusing on excitation and emission sides and its application for sensing.
